\LetLtxMacro\oldtextsc

Latent Abstractions in Generative Diffusion Models

Giulio Franzese1, Mattia Martini2, Giulio Corallo1,3, Paolo Papotti 1, Pietro Michiardi1
1 Department of Data Science, EURECOM, Biot, France,
2 UniversitÃ© CÃ´te dâ€™Azur, CNRS, Laboratoire J. A. DieudonnÃ© , Nice, France
3 SAP Labs, Mougins, France
Abstract

In this work we study how diffusion-based generative models produce high-dimensional data, such as an image, by implicitly relying on a manifestation of a low-dimensional set of latent abstractions, that guide the generative process. We present a novel theoretical framework that extends Nonlinear Filtering (\oldtextscnlf), and that offers a unique perspective on \oldtextscsde-based generative models. The development of our theory relies on a novel formulation of the joint (state and measurement) dynamics, and an information-theoretic measure of the influence of the system state on the measurement process. According to our theory, diffusion models can be cast as a system of \oldtextscsde, describing a non-linear filter in which the evolution of unobservable latent abstractions steers the dynamics of an observable measurement process (corresponding to the generative pathways). In addition, we present an empirical study to validate our theory and previous empirical results on the emergence of latent abstractions at different stages of the generative process.

1 Introduction

Generative models have become a cornerstone of modern machine learning, offering powerful methods for synthesizing high-quality data across various domains such as image and video synthesis (Dhariwal & Nichol, 2021; Ho etÂ al., 2022; He etÂ al., 2022), natural language processingÂ (Li etÂ al., 2022b; He etÂ al., 2023; Gulrajani & Hashimoto, 2023; Lou etÂ al., 2024), audio generation (Kong etÂ al., 2021; Liu etÂ al., 2022), and molecular structures and general 3D shapes (Trippe etÂ al., 2022; Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022; Luo & Hu, 2021; Zeng etÂ al., 2022), to name a few. These models transform an initial distribution, which is simple to sample from, into one that approximates the data distribution. Among these, diffusion-based models designed through the lenses of Stochastic Differential Equations (\oldtextscsdes) (Song etÂ al., 2021; Ho etÂ al., 2020; Albergo etÂ al., 2023) have gained popularity due to their ability to generate realistic and diverse data samples through a series of stochastic transformations.

In such models, the data generation process, as described by a substantial body of empirical research (Chen etÂ al., 2023; Linhardt etÂ al., 2024; Tang etÂ al., 2023), appears to develop according to distinct stages: high-level semantics emerge first, followed by the incorporation of low-level details, culminating in a refinement (denoising) phase. Despite ample evidence, a comprehensive theoretical framework for modeling these dynamics remains underexplored. Indeed, despite recent work on \oldtextscsde-based generative models (Berner etÂ al., 2022; Richter & Berner, 2023; Ye etÂ al., 2022; Raginsky, 2024) shed new lights on such models, they fall short of explicitly investigating the emergence of abstract representations in the generative process. We address this gap by establishing a new framework for elucidating how generative models construct and leverage latent abstractions, approached through the paradigm of \oldtextscnlf (Bain & Crisan, 2009; VanÂ Handel, 2007; Kutschireiter etÂ al., 2020).

\oldtextscnlf is used across diverse engineering domains (Bain & Crisan, 2009), as it provides robust methodologies for the estimation and prediction of a systemâ€™s state amidst uncertainty and noise. \oldtextscnlf enables the inference of dynamic latent variables that define the system state based on observed data, offering a Bayesian interpretation of state evolution and the ability to incorporate stochastic system dynamics. The problem we consider is the following: an unobservable random variable Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is measured through a noisy continuous-time process Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, wherein the influence of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X on the noisy process is described by an observation function Hğ»Hitalic_H, with the noise component modeled as a Brownian motion term. The goal is to estimate the a-posteriori measure Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the variable Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X given the entire historical trajectory of the measurement process Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In this work, we establish a connection between \oldtextscsde-based generative models and \oldtextscnlf by observing that they can be interpreted as simulations of \oldtextscnlf dynamics. In our framework, the latent abstraction, which corresponds to certain real-world properties within the scope of classical nonlinear filtering and remains unaffected in a causal manner by the posterior process Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is implicitly simulated and iteratively refined. We explore the connection between latent abstractions and the a-posteriori process, through the concept of filtrations â€“ broadly defined as collections of progressively increasing information sets â€“ and offer a rigorous theory to study the emergence and influence of latent abstractions throughout the data generation process. Our theoretical contributions unfold as follows.

In Â§Â 2 we show how to reformulate classical \oldtextscnlf results such that the measurement process is the only available information, and derive the corresponding dynamics of both the latent abstraction and the measurement process. These results are summarized in TheoremÂ 2 and TheoremÂ 3.

Given the new dynamics, in TheoremÂ 4 we show how to estimate the a-posteriori measure of the \oldtextscnlf model, and present a novel derivation to compute the mutual information between the measurement process and random variables derived from a transformation of the latent abstractions in TheoremÂ 5. Finally, we show in TheoremÂ 6, that the a-posteriori measure is a sufficient statistics for any random variable derived from the latent abstractions, when only having access to the measurement process.

Building on these general results, in Â§Â 3 we present a novel perspective on continuous-time score-based diffusion models, which is summarised in EquationÂ 10. We propose to view such generative models as \oldtextscnlf simulators that progress in two stages: first our model updates the a-posteriori measure representing a sufficient statistics of the latent abstractions, second, it uses a projection of the a-posteriori measure to update the measurement process. Such intuitive understanding is the result of several fundamental steps. In TheoremÂ 7 and TheoremÂ 8, we show that the common view of score-based diffusion models by which they evolve according to forward (noising) and backward (generative) dynamics is compatible with the \oldtextscnlf formulation, in which there is no need to distinguish between such phases. In other words, the \oldtextscnlf perspective of EquationÂ 10 is a valid generative model. In AppendixÂ H, we provide additional results (see LemmaÂ 1), focusing on the specific case of linear diffusion models, which are the most popular instance of score-based generative models in use today. In Â§Â 4, we summarize the main intuitions behind our \oldtextscnlf framework.

Our results explain, by means of a theoretically sound framework, the emergence of latent abstractions that has been observed by a large body of empirical work (Bisk etÂ al., 2020; Bender & Koller, 2020; Li etÂ al., 2022a; Park etÂ al., 2023; Kwon etÂ al., 2023; Chen etÂ al., 2023; Linhardt etÂ al., 2024; Tang etÂ al., 2023; Xiang etÂ al., 2023; Haas etÂ al., 2024). The closest research to our findings is discussed in (Sclocchi etÂ al., 2024), albeit from a different mathematical perspective. To root our theoretical results in additional empirical evidence, we conclude our work in Â§Â 5 with a series of experiments on score-based generative modelsÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021), where we 1) validate existing probing techniques to measure the emergence of latent abstractions, 2) compute the mutual information as derived in our framework, and show that it is a suitable approach to measure the relation between the generative process and latent abstractions, 3) introduce a new measurement protocol to further confirm the connections between our theory, and how practical diffusion-based generative models operate.

2 Nonlinear Filtering

Consider two random variables Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, corresponding to a stochastic measurement process (Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) of some underlying latent abstraction (Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X). All standard technical assumptions are available in AppendixÂ A.

Next, we provide the necessary background on \oldtextscnlf, to pave the way for understanding its connection with the generative models of interest. The most important building block of the \oldtextscnlf literature is represented by the conditional probability measure Pâ¢[XâˆˆA|â„±tY]Pdelimited-[]ğ‘‹conditionalğ´subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathrm{P}[X\in A\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]roman_P [ italic_X âˆˆ italic_A | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] (notice the reduced filtration â„±tYâŠ‚â„±tY,Xsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘‹ğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}\subset\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), which summarizes, a-posteriori, the distribution of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X given observations of the measurement process until time tğ‘¡titalic_t, that is, Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tsubscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡Y_{0\leq s\leq t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Theorem 1.

[Thm 2.1 (Bain & Crisan, 2009)] Consider the probability triplet (Î©,â„±,P)Î©â„±P(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathrm{P})( roman_Î© , caligraphic_F , roman_P ), the metric space ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S and its Borel sigma-algebra â„¬â¢(ğ’®)â„¬ğ’®\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{S})caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_S ). There exists a (probability measure valued ğ’«â¢(ğ’®)ğ’«ğ’®\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{S})caligraphic_P ( caligraphic_S )) process {Ï€0â‰¤tâ‰¤T,â„±0â‰¤tâ‰¤TY}subscriptğœ‹0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œ0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡\{{{\pi}}_{0\leq t\leq T},\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{0\leq t\leq T}\}{ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t â‰¤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t â‰¤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, with a progressively measurable modification, such that for all Aâˆˆâ„¬â¢(ğ’®)ğ´â„¬ğ’®A\in\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{S})italic_A âˆˆ caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_S ), the conditional probability measure Pâ¢[XâˆˆA|â„±tY]Pdelimited-[]ğ‘‹conditionalğ´subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathrm{P}[X\in A\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]roman_P [ italic_X âˆˆ italic_A | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is well defined and is equal to Ï€tâ¢(A)subscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡ğ´{{\pi}_{t}}(A)italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ).

The conditional probability measure is extremely important, as the fundamental goal of nonlinear filtering is the solution of the following problem. Here, we introduce the quantity Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, which is a random variable derived from the latent abstractions Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X.

Problem 1.

For any fixed Ï•:ğ’®â†’â„:italic-Ï•â†’ğ’®â„\phi:\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}italic_Ï• : caligraphic_S â†’ blackboard_R bounded and measurable, given knowledge of the measurement process Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tsubscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡Y_{0\leq s\leq t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, compute ğ”¼Pâ¢[Ï•â¢(X)|â„±tY]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalitalic-Ï•ğ‘‹subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\phi(X)\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ï• ( italic_X ) | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. This amounts to computing

âŸ¨Ï€t,Ï•âŸ©=âˆ«ğ’®Ï•â¢(x)â¢dÏ€tâ¢(x).subscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptğ’®italic-Ï•ğ‘¥subscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡ğ‘¥\langle{{\pi}_{t}},\phi\rangle=\int_{\mathcal{S}}\phi(x)\differential{{\pi}_{t% }}(x).âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• âŸ© = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• ( italic_x ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) . (2)

In simple terms, 1 involves studying the existence of the a-posteriori measure and the implementation of efficient algorithms for its update, using the flowing stream of incoming information Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We first focus our attention on the existence of an analytic expression for the value of the a-posteriori expected measure Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡{{\pi}_{t}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, we quantify the interaction dynamics between observable measurements and Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, through the lenses of mutual information â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t;Ï•)â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ), which is an extension of the problems considered in (Newton, 2008; Duncan, 1970; 1971; Mitter & Newton, 2003).

2.1 Technical preliminaries

We set the stage of our work by revisiting the measurement process Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and express it in a way that does not require access to unobservable information. Indeed, while Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is naturally adapted w.r.t. its own filtration â„±tYsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and consequently to any other growing filtration â„›tsubscriptâ„›ğ‘¡\mathcal{R}_{t}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such â„±tY,XâŠ‡â„›tâŠ‡â„±tYsuperset-of-or-equalssubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘‹ğ‘¡subscriptâ„›ğ‘¡superset-of-or-equalssubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}_{t}\supseteq\mathcal{R}_{t}\supseteq\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‡ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‡ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the representation in EquationÂ 1 is in general not adapted, letting aside degenerate cases.

Letâ€™s consider the family of growing filtrations â„›t=Ïƒâ¢(â„›0âˆªÏƒâ¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tâˆ’Y0))subscriptâ„›ğ‘¡ğœsubscriptâ„›0ğœsubscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0\mathcal{R}_{t}=\sigma(\mathcal{R}_{0}\cup\sigma(Y_{0\leq s\leq t}-Y_{0}))caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), where Ïƒâ¢(Y0)âŠ†â„›0âŠ†Ïƒâ¢(X,Y0)ğœsubscriptğ‘Œ0subscriptâ„›0ğœğ‘‹subscriptğ‘Œ0\sigma(Y_{0})\subseteq\mathcal{R}_{0}\subseteq\sigma(X,Y_{0})italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âŠ† caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Intuitively â„›0subscriptâ„›0\mathcal{R}_{0}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT allows to modulate between the two extreme cases of knowing only the initial conditions of the \oldtextscsde, that is Y0subscriptğ‘Œ0Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, to the case of complete knowledge of the whole latent abstraction Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, and anything in between. As shown hereafter, the original process Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT associated to the space (Î©,â„±,P)Î©â„±P(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathrm{P})( roman_Î© , caligraphic_F , roman_P ) which solves EquationÂ 1, also solves EquationÂ 4, that is adapted on the reduced filtration â„›tsubscriptâ„›ğ‘¡\mathcal{R}_{t}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This allows us to reason about the partial observation of the latent abstraction (â„›0subscriptâ„›0\mathcal{R}_{0}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT vs Ïƒâ¢(X,Y0)ğœğ‘‹subscriptğ‘Œ0\sigma(X,Y_{0})italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )), without incurring in the problem of the measurement process Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being statistically dependent of the whole latent abstraction Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X.

Armed with such representation, we study under which change of measure the process Ytâˆ’Y0subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0Y_{t}-Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT behaves as a Brownian motion (TheoremÂ 3). This serves the purpose of simplifying the calculation of the expected value of Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• given Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as described in 1. Indeed, if Ytâˆ’Y0subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0Y_{t}-Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Brownian motion independent of Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, its knowledge does not influence our best guess for Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, i.e. the conditional expected value. Moreover, our alternative representation is instrumental for the efficient and simple computation of the mutual information â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t;Ï•)â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ), where the different measures involved in the Radon-Nikodym derivatives will be compared against the same reference Brownian measures.

The first step to define our representation is provided by the following

Theorem 2.

[Proof]. Consider the the probability triplet (Î©,â„±,P)Î©â„±P(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathrm{P})( roman_Î© , caligraphic_F , roman_P ), the process in EquationÂ 1 defined on it, and the growing filtration â„›t=Ïƒâ¢(â„›0âˆªÏƒâ¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tâˆ’Y0))subscriptâ„›ğ‘¡ğœsubscriptâ„›0ğœsubscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0\mathcal{R}_{t}=\sigma(\mathcal{R}_{0}\cup\sigma(Y_{0\leq s\leq t}-Y_{0}))caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). Define a new stochastic process

Theorem 3.

[Proof]. A direct consequence of TheoremÂ 3 is that the process W~tsubscript~ğ‘Šğ‘¡\tilde{W}_{t}over~ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is independent of any â„›0subscriptâ„›0\mathcal{R}_{0}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measurable random variable under the measure Qâ„›superscriptQâ„›{\mathrm{Q}^{\mathcal{R}}}roman_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. 2.2 A-Posteriori Measure and Mutual Information

As we did in Â§Â 2 for the process Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, here we introduce a new process Ï€tâ„›subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›ğ‘¡\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which represents the conditional law of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X given the filtration â„›t=Ïƒâ¢(â„›0âˆªÏƒâ¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tâˆ’Y0))subscriptâ„›ğ‘¡ğœsubscriptâ„›0ğœsubscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0\mathcal{R}_{t}=\sigma(\mathcal{R}_{0}\cup\sigma(Y_{0\leq s\leq t}-Y_{0}))caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). More precisely, for all Aâˆˆâ„¬â¢(ğ’®)ğ´â„¬ğ’®A\in\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{S})italic_A âˆˆ caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_S ), the conditional probability measure Pâ¢[XâˆˆA|â„›t]Pdelimited-[]ğ‘‹conditionalğ´subscriptâ„›ğ‘¡\mathrm{P}[X\in A\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{t}]roman_P [ italic_X âˆˆ italic_A | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is well defined and is equal to Ï€tâ„›â¢(A)subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›ğ‘¡ğ´\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}(A)italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ). Moreover, for any Ï•:ğ’®â†’â„:italic-Ï•â†’ğ’®â„\phi:\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}italic_Ï• : caligraphic_S â†’ blackboard_R bounded and measurable, ğ”¼Pâ¢[Ï•â¢(X)|â„›t]=âŸ¨Ï€tâ„›,Ï•âŸ©subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalitalic-Ï•ğ‘‹subscriptâ„›ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›ğ‘¡italic-Ï•\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\phi(X)\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{t}]=\langle\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_% {t},\phi\rangleblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ï• ( italic_X ) | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• âŸ©. Notice that if â„›=â„±Yâ„›superscriptâ„±ğ‘Œ\mathcal{R}=\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_R = caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT then Ï€â„›superscriptğœ‹â„›\pi^{\mathcal{R}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT reduces to Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€.

Armed with TheoremÂ 3, we are ready to derive the expression for the a-posteriori measure Ï€tâ„›subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›ğ‘¡\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the mutual information between observable measurements and the unavailable information about the latent abstractions, that materialize in the random variable Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•.

Theorem 4.

[Proof]. The measure-valued process Ï€tâ„›subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›ğ‘¡\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT solves in weak sense (see AppendixÂ D for a precise definition), the following \oldtextscsde

Ï€tâ„›=Ï€0â„›+âˆ«0tÏ€sâ„›â¢(Hâ¢(Ys,â‹…,s)âˆ’âŸ¨Ï€sâ„›,Hâ¢(Ys,â‹…,s)âŸ©)â¢(dYsâˆ’âŸ¨Ï€sâ„›,Hâ¢(Ys,â‹…,s)âŸ©â¢ds),subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›0superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›ğ‘ ğ»subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ â‹…ğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›ğ‘ ğ»subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ â‹…ğ‘ subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›ğ‘ ğ»subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ â‹…ğ‘ ğ‘ \displaystyle\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}=\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\pi^{% \mathcal{R}}_{s}\left(H(Y_{s},\cdot,s)-\langle\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{s},H(Y_{s},% \cdot,s)\rangle\right)\left(\differential Y_{s}-\langle\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{s},H% (Y_{s},\cdot,s)\rangle\differential s\right),italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹… , italic_s ) - âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹… , italic_s ) âŸ© ) ( start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹… , italic_s ) âŸ© start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ) , (6)

where the initial condition Ï€0subscriptğœ‹0\pi_{0}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies Ï€0â„›â¢(A)=Pâ¢[XâˆˆA|â„›0]subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›0ğ´Pdelimited-[]ğ‘‹conditionalğ´subscriptâ„›0\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{0}(A)=\mathrm{P}[X\in A\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{0}]italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ) = roman_P [ italic_X âˆˆ italic_A | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] for all Aâˆˆâ„¬â¢(ğ’®)ğ´â„¬ğ’®A\in\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{S})italic_A âˆˆ caligraphic_B ( caligraphic_S ).

When â„›=â„±Yâ„›superscriptâ„±ğ‘Œ\mathcal{R}=\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_R = caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, EquationÂ 6 is the well-know Kushner-Stratonovitch (or Fujisaki-Kallianpur-Kunita) equation (see e.g.Â Bain & Crisan (2009)). A proof for uniqueness of the solution of EquationÂ 6 can be approached by considering the strategies in (Fotsa-Mbogne & Pardoux, 2017), but is outside the scope of this work. The (recursive) expression in EquationÂ 6 is particularly useful for engineering purposes since, in general, it is usually not known in which variables Ï•â¢(X)italic-Ï•ğ‘‹\phi(X)italic_Ï• ( italic_X ), representing latent abstractions, we could be interested in. Keeping track of the whole distribution Ï€tâ„›subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹â„›ğ‘¡\pi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at time tğ‘¡titalic_t is the most cost-effective solution, as we will show later.

Our next goal is to quantify the interaction dynamics between observable measurements and latent abstractions that materialize through the variable Ï•â¢(X)italic-Ï•ğ‘‹\phi(X)italic_Ï• ( italic_X ) (from now on we write only Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• for the sake of brevity): in TheoremÂ 5 we derive the mutual information â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t;Ï•)â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ).

Theorem 5.

[Proof] The mutual information between observable measurements Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tsubscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡Y_{0\leq s\leq t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• is defined as:

â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t;Ï•)=defâˆ«logâ¡dP#â¢Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t,Ï•dP#â¢Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tâ¢dP#â¢Ï•â¢dP#â¢Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t,Ï•.superscriptdefâ„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptP#subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptP#subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptP#italic-Ï•subscriptP#subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}% \int\log\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t},\phi}}{% \differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t}}\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#\phi}}% \differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t},\phi}.caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ) start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP âˆ« roman_log divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (7)

It holds that such quantity is equal to ğ”¼Pâ¢[logâ¡dP|â„›tdP|â„±tYâ¢dP|Ïƒâ¢(Ï•)]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]evaluated-atPsubscriptâ„›ğ‘¡evaluated-atevaluated-atPsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡Pğœitalic-Ï•\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}\left[\log\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{% R}_{t}}}{\differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}}\differential% \mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\sigma(\phi)}}\right]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï• ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ], which can be simplified as follows:

â„â¢(Y0;Ï•)+12â¢ğ”¼Pâ¢[âˆ«0tâ€–ğ”¼Pâ¢[Hâ¢(X,Ys,s)|â„±sY]âˆ’ğ”¼Pâ¢[Hâ¢(X,Ys,s)|â„›s]â€–2â¢ds].â„subscriptğ‘Œ0italic-Ï•12subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡superscriptnormsubscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalğ»ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘ subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalğ»ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘ subscriptâ„›ğ‘ 2ğ‘ \mathcal{I}(Y_{0};\phi)+\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}\left[\int_{0}^{t}% \norm{\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[H(X,Y_{s},s)\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{s}]-\mathbb{E}% _{\mathrm{P}}[H(X,Y_{s},s)\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{s}]}^{2}\differential s\right].caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_H ( italic_X , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s ) | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_H ( italic_X , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s ) | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ] . (8)

The mutual information computed by EquationÂ 8 is composed by two elements: first, the mutual information between the initial measurements Y0subscriptğ‘Œ0Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, which is typically zero by construction. The second term quantifies how much the best prediction of the observation function Hğ»Hitalic_H is influenced by the extra knowledge of Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, in addition to the measurement history Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tsubscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡Y_{0\leq s\leq t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By adhering to the premise that the conditional expectation of a stochastic variable constitutes the optimal estimator given the conditioning information, the integral on the r.h.s quantifies the expected square difference between predictions, having access to measurements only (ğ”¼P[â‹…|â„±tY]\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\cdot\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ â‹… | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]) and those incorporating additional information (ğ”¼P[â‹…|â„›t]\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\cdot\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{t}]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ â‹… | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]).

Even though a precise characterization for general observation functions and and variables Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• is typically out of reach, a qualitative analysis is possible. First, the mutual information between Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• and the measurements depends on i) how much the amplitude of Hğ»Hitalic_H is impacted by knowledge of Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• and ii) the number of elements of Hğ»Hitalic_H which are impacted (informally, how much localized vs global is the impact of Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•). Second, it is possible to define a hierarchical interpretation about the emergence of the various latent factors: a variable with a local impact can â€œappearâ€, in an information theoretic sense, only if the impact of other global variables is resolved, otherwise the remaining uncertainty of the global variables makes knowledge of the local variable irrelevant. In classical diffusion models, this is empirically known (Chen etÂ al., 2023; Linhardt etÂ al., 2024; Tang etÂ al., 2023), and corresponds to the phenomenon where semantics emerges before details (global vs local details in our language).

Now, consider any â„±tYsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measurable random variable Y~tsubscript~ğ‘Œğ‘¡\tilde{Y}_{t}over~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, defined as a mapping to a generic measurable space (Î¨,â„¬â¢(Î¨))Î¨â„¬Î¨(\Psi,\mathcal{B}(\Psi))( roman_Î¨ , caligraphic_B ( roman_Î¨ ) ), which means it can also be seen as a process. The data processing inequality states that the mutual information between such Y~~ğ‘Œ\tilde{Y}over~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG and Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• will be smaller than the mutual information between the original measurement process and Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•. However, it can be shown that all the relevant information about the random variable Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• contained in â„±tYsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is equivalently contained in the filtering process at time instant tğ‘¡titalic_t, that is Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is not trivial, since Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a â„±tYsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-measurable quantity, i.e., Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)âŠ‚â„±tYğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\sigma(\pi_{t})\subset\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âŠ‚ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In other words, we show that Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a sufficient statistic for any Ïƒâ¢(X)ğœğ‘‹\sigma(X)italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X ) measurable random variable when starting from the measurement process.

Theorem 6.

[Proof] For any â„±tYsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measurable random variable Y~t:Î©â†’Î¨:subscript~ğ‘Œğ‘¡â†’Î©Î¨\tilde{Y}_{t}:\Omega\rightarrow\Psiover~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : roman_Î© â†’ roman_Î¨, the following inequality holds:

â„â¢(Y~;Ï•)â‰¤â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t;Ï•).â„~ğ‘Œitalic-Ï•â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•\mathcal{I}(\tilde{Y};\phi)\leq\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi).caligraphic_I ( over~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG ; italic_Ï• ) â‰¤ caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ) . (9)

For a given tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0, the measurement process Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tsubscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡Y_{0\leq s\leq t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X are conditionally-independent given Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This implies that Pâ¢(A|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t))=Pâ¢(A|â„±tY),âˆ€AâˆˆÏƒâ¢(X)formulae-sequencePconditionalğ´ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡Pconditionalğ´subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡for-allğ´ğœğ‘‹\mathrm{P}(A\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t}))=\mathrm{P}(A\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}),\quad% \forall A\in\sigma(X)roman_P ( italic_A | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = roman_P ( italic_A | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , âˆ€ italic_A âˆˆ italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X ). Then â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t;Ï•)=â„â¢(Ï€t;Ï•)â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•â„subscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡italic-Ï•\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)=\mathcal{I}(\pi_{t};\phi)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ) = caligraphic_I ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ) (i.e. EquationÂ 9 is attained with equality).

While Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains all the relevant information about Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, the same cannot be said about the conditional expectation, i.e. the particular case Y~=âŸ¨Ï€t,Ï•âŸ©~ğ‘Œsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡italic-Ï•\tilde{Y}=\langle\pi_{t},\phi\rangleover~ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG = âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• âŸ©. Indeed, from EquationÂ 2, âŸ¨Ï€t,Ï•âŸ©subscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡italic-Ï•\langle\pi_{t},\phi\rangleâŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• âŸ© is obtained as a transformation of Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and thus can be interpreted as a â„±tYsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measurable quantity subject to the constraint of EquationÂ 9. As a particular case, the quantity âŸ¨Ï€t,HâŸ©subscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡ğ»\langle{{\pi}_{t}},H\rangleâŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H âŸ©, of central importance in the construction of generative models Â§Â 3, carries in general less information about Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• than the un-projected Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

3 Generative Modelling

We are interested in generative models for a given Ïƒâ¢(X)ğœğ‘‹\sigma(X)italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X )-measurable random variable Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V. An intuitive illustration of how data generation works according to our framework is as follows. Consider, for example, the image domain, and the availability of a rendering engine that takes as an input a computer program describing a scene (coordinates of objects, textures, light sources, auxiliary labels, etc â€¦) and that produces an output image of the scene. In a similar vein, a generative model learns how to use latent variables (which are not explicitly provided in input, but rather implicitly learned through training) to generate an image. For such model to work, one valid strategy is to consider an \oldtextscsde in the form of EquationÂ 1 where the following holds111 From a strict technical point of view, 1 might be incompatible with other assumptions in AppendixÂ A, or proving compatibility could require particular effort. Such details are discussed in AppendixÂ G. .

Assumption 1.

The stochastic process Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies YT=V,Pâˆ’a.s.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡ğ‘‰Pğ‘ğ‘ Y_{T}=V,\quad\mathrm{P}-a.s.italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V , roman_P - italic_a . italic_s .

Then, we could numerically simulate the dynamics of EquationÂ 1 until time Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. Indeed, starting from initial conditions Y0subscriptğ‘Œ0Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we could obtain YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that, under 1, is precisely Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V. Unfortunately, such a simple idea requires explicit access to Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, as it is evident from EquationÂ 1. In mathematical terms, EquationÂ 1 is adapted to the filtration â„±tY,Xsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘‹ğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, we have shown how to reduce the available information to account only for historical values of Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, we can combine the result in TheoremÂ 4 with TheoremÂ 2 and re-interpret EquationÂ 4, which is a valid generative model, as

{Ï€t=Ï€0+âˆ«0tÏ€sâ¢(Hâˆ’âŸ¨Ï€s,HâŸ©)â¢(dYsâˆ’âŸ¨Ï€s,HâŸ©â¢ds),Yt=Y0+âˆ«0tâŸ¨Ï€s,HâŸ©â¢ds+Wtâ„±Y,casessubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‹0superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ ğ»subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ ğ»subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ ğ»ğ‘ otherwisesubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ ğ»ğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡otherwise\begin{cases}\pi_{t}=\pi_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\pi_{s}\left(H-\langle{{\pi}_{s}},H% \rangle\right)\left(\differential Y_{s}-\langle{{\pi}_{s}},H\rangle% \differential s\right),\\ Y_{t}=Y_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\langle{{\pi}_{s}},H\rangle\differential s+{W}^{% \mathcal{F}^{Y}}_{t},\end{cases}{ start_ROW start_CELL italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_H - âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H âŸ© ) ( start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H âŸ© start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ) , end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H âŸ© start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW (10)

where Hğ»Hitalic_H denotes Hâ¢(Ys,â‹…,s)ğ»subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ â‹…ğ‘ H(Y_{s},\cdot,s)italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹… , italic_s ). Explicit simulation of EquationÂ 10 only requires knowledge of the whole history of the measurement process: provided 1 holds, it allows generation of a sample of the random variable Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V.

Although the discussion in this work includes a large class of observation functions, we focus on the particular case of generative diffusion models (Song etÂ al., 2021). Typically, such models are presented through the lenses of a forward noising process and backward (in time) \oldtextscsdes, following the intuition of Anderson (1982). Next, according to the framework we introduce in this work, we reinterpret such models under the perspective of enlargement of filtrations.

Consider the reversed process Y^t=defYTâˆ’tsuperscriptdefsubscript^ğ‘Œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡ğ‘¡\hat{Y}_{t}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}Y_{T-t}over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT defined on (Î©,â„±,P)Î©â„±P(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathrm{P})( roman_Î© , caligraphic_F , roman_P ) and the corresponding filtration â„±tY^=defÏƒâ¢(Y^0â‰¤sâ‰¤t)superscriptdefsuperscriptsubscriptâ„±ğ‘¡^ğ‘Œğœsubscript^ğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{F}_{t}^{\hat{Y}}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\sigma(\hat{Y% }_{0\leq s\leq t})caligraphic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_Ïƒ ( over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Note that EquationÂ 11, albeit with a different notation, is reminiscent of the forward \oldtextscsde that is typically used as the starting point to illustrate score-based generative modelsÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021). In particular, Fâ¢(â‹…)ğ¹â‹…F(\cdot)italic_F ( â‹… ) corresponds to the drift term of such a diffusion \oldtextscsde.

EquationÂ 11 is equivalent to Yt=V+âˆ«tTFâ¢(Ys,Tâˆ’s)â¢ds+W^Tâˆ’tsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ‘‰superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘ ğ‘ subscript^ğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ‘¡Y_{t}=V+\int\limits_{t}^{T}F(Y_{s},T-s)\differential s+\hat{W}_{T-t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V + âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T - italic_s ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is an expression for the process Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is adapted to â„±Y^superscriptâ„±^ğ‘Œ\mathcal{F}^{\hat{Y}}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This constitutes the first step to derive an equivalent backward (generative) process according to the traditional framework of score-based diffusion models. Note that such an equivalent representation is not useful for simulation purposes: the goals of the next steps is to transform it such that it is adapted to â„±Ysuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œ\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Indeed, using simple algebra, it holds that

Theorem 7.

Consider the stochastic process Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which solves EquationÂ 11. (12)

EquationÂ 12 corresponds to the backward diffusion process fromÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021) and, because it is adapted to the filtration â„±Ysuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œ\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, it represents a valid, and easy to simulate, measurement process.

By now, it is clear how to go from an â„±Y,Xsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘‹\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ€“adapted filtration to a â„±Ysuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œ\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ€“adapted one. We also showed that a â„±Ysuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œ\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ€“adapted filtration can be linked to the reverse, â„±Y^superscriptâ„±^ğ‘Œ\mathcal{F}^{\hat{Y}}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ€“adapted process induced by a forward diffusion \oldtextscsde. What remains to be discussed is the connection that exists between the â„±Ysuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œ\mathcal{F}^{Y}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTâ€“adapted filtration, and its enlarged version â„±Y,Xsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘‹\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In other words, we have shown that a forward, diffusion \oldtextscsde admits a backward process which is compatible with our generative model that simulates a \oldtextscnlf process having access only to measurements, but we need to make sure that such process admits a formulation that is compatible the standard \oldtextscnlf framework in which latent abstractions are available.

To do this, we can leverage existing results about Markovian bridgesÂ (Rogers & Williams, 2000; Ye etÂ al., 2022) (and further workÂ (Aksamit etÂ al., 2017; Ouwehand, 2022; Grigorian & Jarrow, 2023; Ã‡etin & Danilova, 2016) on filtration enlargement). This requires assumptions about the existence and well-behavedness of densities pâ¢(y,t)ğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘¡p(y,t)italic_p ( italic_y , italic_t ) of the \oldtextscsde process, defined by the logarithm of the Radon-Nikodym derivative of the instantaneous measure Pâ¢(Ytâˆˆdy)Psubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ‘¦\mathrm{P}(Y_{t}\in\differential y)roman_P ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y ) w.r.t. the Lebesgue measure in â„Nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘\mathbb{R}^{N}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Pâ¢(Ytâˆˆdy)=pâ¢(y,t)â¢dyPsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘¡ğ‘¦\mathrm{P}(Y_{t}\in\differential y)=p(y,t)\differential yroman_P ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y ) = italic_p ( italic_y , italic_t ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y222Similarly to what discussed in footnote 1, the analysis of the existence of the process adapted to â„±tYsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is considered in the time interval [0,T)0ğ‘‡[0,T)[ 0 , italic_T ) (Haussmann & Pardoux, 1986). See also AppendixÂ G..

Theorem 8.

where {W0â‰¤tâ‰¤T,â„±0â‰¤tâ‰¤TY}subscriptğ‘Š0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œ0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡\{W_{0\leq t\leq T},\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{0\leq t\leq T}\}{ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t â‰¤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t â‰¤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is a Brownian motion and Fğ¹Fitalic_F satisfies the requirements for existence and well definition of the stochastic integral (Shreve, 2004). Yt=Y0+âˆ«0tFâ€²â¢(Ys,s)+âˆ‡Yslogâ¡pâ¢(YT|Ys)â¢ds+Î²t,subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡superscriptğ¹â€²subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘ subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘ subscriptğ›½ğ‘¡Y_{t}=Y_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}F^{\prime}(Y_{s},s)+\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{T}\,|\,Y_{% s})\differential s+\beta_{t},italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s ) + âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (14)

where pâ¢(YT|Ys)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ p(Y_{T}\,|\,Y_{s})italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the density w.r.t the Lebesgue measure of the probability Pâ¢(YT|Ïƒâ¢(Ys))Pconditionalsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡ğœsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘ \mathrm{P}(Y_{T}\,|\,\sigma(Y_{s}))roman_P ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), and {Î²0â‰¤tâ‰¤T,â„›0â‰¤tâ‰¤T}subscriptğ›½0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptâ„›0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡\{\beta_{0\leq t\leq T},\mathcal{R}_{0\leq t\leq T}\}{ italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t â‰¤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t â‰¤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is a Brownian motion.

The connection between time reversal of diffusion processes and enlarged filtrations is finalized with the result of Al-Hussaini & Elliott (1987), Thm. 3.3, where it is proved how the Î²tsubscriptğ›½ğ‘¡\beta_{t}italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT term of EquationÂ 14 is a Brownian motion, using the techniques of time reversals of \oldtextscsdes.

Since p^â¢(y,Tâˆ’t)=pâ¢(y,t)^ğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘¡\hat{p}(y,T-t)={p}(y,t)over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG ( italic_y , italic_T - italic_t ) = italic_p ( italic_y , italic_t ), the enlarged filtration version of EquationÂ 12 reads

Yt=Y0+âˆ«0tâˆ’Fâ¢(Ys,Tâˆ’s)+âˆ‡Yslogâ¡pâ¢(Ys|YT)â¢dsâŸEquivalent toÂ â¢Hâ¢(Yt,X,t)=âˆ’Fâ¢(Ys,Tâˆ’s)+âˆ‡Yslogâ¡pâ¢(Ys|gâ¢(X))+Wt.subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡subscriptâŸğ¹subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘ subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘ subscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡ğ‘ Equivalent toÂ ğ»subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ¹subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘ subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘”ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡Y_{t}=Y_{0}+\int_{0}^{t}\underbrace{-F(Y_{s},T-s)+\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{s}\,% |\,Y_{T})\differential s}_{\text{Equivalent to }H(Y_{t},X,t)=-F(Y_{s},T-s)+% \nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{s}\,|\,g(X))}+W_{t}.italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT underâŸ start_ARG - italic_F ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T - italic_s ) + âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Equivalent to italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X , italic_t ) = - italic_F ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T - italic_s ) + âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_g ( italic_X ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (15)

Note that the dependence of Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the latent abstractions Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is implicitly defined by conditioning the score term âˆ‡Yslogâ¡pâ¢(Ys|YT)subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘ subscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{s}\,|\,Y_{T})âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is the â€œrenderingâ€ of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X into the observable data domain.

Clearly, EquationÂ 15 can be reverted to the starting generative EquationÂ 12 by mimicking the results which allowed us to go from EquationÂ 1 to EquationÂ 4, by noticing that ğ”¼Pâ¢[âˆ‡Yslogâ¡pâ¢(YT|Ys)|â„±tY]=0subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡0\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = 0 (informally, this is obtained since âˆ«âˆ‡yslogâ¡pâ¢(yt|ys)â¢pâ¢(yt|ys)â¢dyt=âˆ«âˆ‡yspâ¢(yt|ys)â¢dyt=0subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡0\int\nabla_{y_{s}}\log end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_p ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ« âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0).

It is also important to notice that we can derive the expression for the mutual information between the measurement process and a sample from the data distribution, as follows

â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t;V)=â„â¢(Y0;V)+12â¢ğ”¼Pâ¢[âˆ«0tâ€–âˆ‡Yslogâ¡pâ¢(Ys)âˆ’âˆ‡Yslogâ¡pâ¢(Ys|YT)â€–2â¢ds].â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‰â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘‰12subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡superscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘ subscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡2ğ‘ \mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};V)=\mathcal{I}(Y_{0};V)+\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{% \mathrm{P}}\left[\int_{0}^{t}\norm{\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{s})-\nabla_{Y_{s}}% \log p(Y_{s}\,|\,Y_{T})}^{2}\differential s\right].caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_V ) = caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_V ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_ARG âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ] . (16)

Mutual information is tightly related to the classical loss function of generative diffusion models.

Furthermore, by casting the result of EquationÂ 8 according to the forms of EquationsÂ 12 andÂ 15, we obtain the simple and elegant expression

â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t;V)=â„â¢(Y0;V)+12â¢ğ”¼Pâ¢[âˆ«0tâ€–âˆ‡Yslogâ¡pâ¢(YT|Ys)â€–2â¢ds].â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‰â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘‰12subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡superscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ 2ğ‘ \mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};V)=\mathcal{I}(Y_{0};V)+\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{% \mathrm{P}}\left[\int_{0}^{t}\norm{\nabla_{Y_{s}}\log p(Y_{T}\,|\,Y_{s})}^{2}% \differential s\right].caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_V ) = caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_V ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_ARG âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ] . (17)

In AppendixÂ H, we present a specialization of our framework for the particular case of linear diffusion models, recovering the expressions for the variance-preserving and variance-exploding \oldtextscsdes that are the foundations of score-based generative modelsÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021).

4 An informal summary of the results

We shall now take a step back from the rigour of this work, and provide an intuitive summary of our results, using FigureÂ 1 as a reference.

We begin with an illustration of \oldtextscnlf, shown on the left of the figure. We consider an observable latent abstraction Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and the measurement process Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which for ease of illustration we consider evolving in discrete time, i.e. Y0,Y1,â€¦subscriptğ‘Œ0subscriptğ‘Œ1â€¦Y_{0},Y_{1},\dotsitalic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦, and whose joint evolution is described by EquationÂ 1. Such interaction is shown in blue: Y3subscriptğ‘Œ3Y_{3}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depends on its immediate past Y2subscriptğ‘Œ2Y_{2}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the latent abstraction Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X.

The a-posteriori measure process Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is updated in an iterative fashion, by integrating the flux of information. We show this in green: Ï€1subscriptğœ‹1\pi_{1}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is obtained by updating Ï€0subscriptğœ‹0\pi_{0}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with Y1âˆ’Y0subscriptğ‘Œ1subscriptğ‘Œ0Y_{1}-Y_{0}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (the equivalent of dYtsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡\differential Y_{t}start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). This evolution is described by Kushnerâ€™s equation, which has been derived informally from the result of EquationÂ 6. The a-posteriori process is a sufficient statistic for the latent abstraction Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X: for example, Ï€3subscriptğœ‹3\pi_{3}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains the same information about Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• than the whole Y0,â€¦,Y3subscriptğ‘Œ0â€¦subscriptğ‘Œ3Y_{0},\dots,Y_{3}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (red boxes). Instead, in general, a projected statistic âŸ¨Ï€t,Ï•âŸ©subscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡italic-Ï•\langle\pi_{t},{\phi}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• âŸ© contains less information than the whole measurement process (this is shown in orange, for time instant 2). The mutual information between all these variables is proven in TheoremÂ 6, whereas the actual value of â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t;Ï•)â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ) is shown in TheoremÂ 5.

Next, we focus on generative modelling. As by our definition, any stochastic process satisfying 1 (Y3=Vsubscriptğ‘Œ3ğ‘‰Y_{3}=Vitalic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V, in the figure) can be used for generative purposes. Since the latent abstraction is by definition not available, it is not possible to simulate directly the dynamics using EquationÂ 1 (dashed lines from Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X to Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Instead, we derive a version of the process adapted to the history of Ytsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡Y_{t}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT alone, together with the update of the projection âŸ¨Ï€t,HâŸ©subscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡ğ»\langle\pi_{t},H\rangleâŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H âŸ©, which amounts to simulating EquationÂ 10.

The update of the upper part of EquationÂ 10, which is a particular case of EquationÂ 6, can be interpreted as the composition of two steps: 1) (green) the update of the a-posteriori measure given new available measurements, and, 2) (orange) the projection of the whole Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into the statistic of interest. The update of the measurement process, i.e. the lower part of EquationÂ 10, is color-coded in blue. This is in stark contrast to the \oldtextscnlf case, as the update of e.g. Y3=Vsubscriptğ‘Œ3ğ‘‰Y_{3}=Vitalic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V does not depend directly on Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X. The system in EquationÂ 10 and its simulation describes the emergence of latent world representations in \oldtextscsde-based generative models:

The theory developed in this work guarantees that the mutual information between measurements and any statistics Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, grows as described by TheoremÂ 5. Our framework offers a new perspective, according to which, the dynamics of \oldtextscsde-based generative modelsÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021) implicitly mimic the two steps procedure described in the box above. We claim that this is the reason why it is possible to dissect the parametric drift of such generative models and find a representation of the abstract state distribution Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡{{\pi}_{t}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, encoded into their activations. Next, we set to root our theoretical findings in experimental evidence.

5 Empirical Evidence

We complement existing empirical studies (Park etÂ al., 2023; Kwon etÂ al., 2023; Chen etÂ al., 2023; Linhardt etÂ al., 2024; Tang etÂ al., 2023; Xiang etÂ al., 2023; Haas etÂ al., 2024; Sclocchi etÂ al., 2024) that first measured the interactions between the generative process of diffusion models and latent abstractions, by focusing on a particular dataset that allows for a fine grained assessment of the influence of latent factors.

Dataset. We use the Shapes3D (Kim & Mnih, 2018) dataset, which is a collection of 64Ã—64646464\times 6464 Ã— 64 ray-tracing generated images, depicting simple 3D-scenes, with an object (a sphere, cube, â€¦) placed in a space, described by several attributes (color, size, orientation). Attributes have been derived from the computer program that the ray-tracing software executed to generate the scene: these are transformed into labels associated to each image. In our experiments, such labels are the materialization of the latent abstractions Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X we consider in this work (see Â§Â J.1 for details).

Measurement Protocols. For our experiments, we use the base \oldtextscncspp model described by Â Song etÂ al. (2021): specifically, our denoising score network corresponds to a \oldtextscu-netÂ (Ronneberger etÂ al., 2015). We train the unconditional version of this model from scratch, using score-matching objective. Detailed hyper-parameters and training settings are provided inÂ Â§Â J.2. Next, we summarize three techniques to measure the emergence of latent abstractions through the lenses of the labels associated to each image in our dataset. For all such techniques, we use a specific â€œmeasurementâ€ subset of our dataset, which we partition in 246 training, 150 validation, and 371 test examples. We use a multi-label stratification algorithm (Sechidis etÂ al., 2011; SzymaÅ„ski & Kajdanowicz, 2017) to guarantee a balanced distribution of labels across all dataset splits.

Linear probing. Each image in the measurement subset is perturbed with noise, using a variance-exploding scheduleÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021), with noise levels increasing from 0 to 1 in steps of 0.1, as shown inÂ FigureÂ 2. We extract several feature maps from all the linear and convolutional layers of the denoising score network, for each perturbed image, resulting in a total of 162 feature map sets for each noise level. This process yields 11 different datasets per layer, which we use to train a linear classifier (our probe) for each of these datasets, using the training subset. In these experiments, we use a batch size of 64 and adjust the learning rate based on the noise level (seeÂ Â§Â J.3). Classifier performance is optimized by selecting models based on their log-probability accuracy observed on the validation subset. The final evaluation of each classifier is conducted on the test subset. Classification accuracy, measured by the model log likelihood, is a proxy of latent abstraction emergenceÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2023).

Mutual information estimation. We estimate mutual information between the labels and the outputs of the diffusion model across varying diffusion times, using EquationÂ 39 (which is a specialized version of our theory for linear diffusion models, see AppendixÂ H) and adopt the same methodology discussed by Franzese etÂ al. (2024) to learn conditional and unconditional score functions, and to approximate the mutual information. The training process uses a randomized conditioning scheme: 33% of training instances are conditioned on all labels, 33% on a single label, and the remaining 33% are trained unconditionally. SeeÂ Â§Â J.4 for additional details.

Forking. We propose a new technique to measure at which stage of the generative process, image features described by our labels emerge. Given an initial noise sample, we proceed with numerical integration of the backward \oldtextscsdeÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021) up to time Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. At this point, we fork kğ‘˜kitalic_k replicas of the backward process, and continue the kğ‘˜kitalic_k generative pathways independently until numerical integration concludes. We use a simple classifier (a pre-trained ResNet50Â (He etÂ al., 2016) with an additional linear layer trained from scratch) to verify that labels are coherent across the kğ‘˜kitalic_k forks. Coherency is measured using the entropy of the label distribution output by our simple classifier on each latent factor for all the kğ‘˜kitalic_k forks. Intuitively: if we fork the process at time Ï„=0.6ğœ0.6\tau=0.6italic_Ï„ = 0.6, and the kğ‘˜kitalic_k forks all end up displaying a cube in the image (entropy equals 0), this implies that the object shape is a latent abstraction that has already emerged by time Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. Conversely, lack of coherence implies that such a latent factor has not yet influenced the generative process. Details of the classifier training and sampling procedure are provided inÂ Â§Â J.5.

Results. We present our results in FigureÂ 3. We note that some attributes like floor hue, wall hue and shape emerge earlier than others, which corroborates the hierarchical nature of latent abstractions, a phenomenon that is related to the spatial extent of each attribute in pixel space. This is evident from the results of linear probing, where we evaluate the performance of linear probes trained on features maps extracted from the denoiser network, and from the mutual information measurement strategy and the measured entropy of the predicted labels across forked generative pathways. Entropy decreases with Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, which marks the moment in which the generative process proceeds along kğ‘˜kitalic_k forks. When generative pathways converge to a unique scene with identical predicted labels (entropy reaches zero), this means that the model has committed to a specific set of latent factors. This coincides with the same noise level corresponding to high accuracy for the linear probe, and high-values of mutual information. Further ablation experiments are presented in Â§Â J.6.

6 Conclusion

Despite their tremendous success in many practical applications, a deep understanding of how \oldtextscsde-based generative models operate remained elusive. A particularly intriguing aspect of several empirical work was to uncover the capacity of generative models to create entirely new data by combining latent factors learned from examples. To the best of our knowledge, there exist no theoretical framework that attempted at describing such phenomenon.

In this work, we closed this gap, and presented a novel theory â€” that builds on the framework of \oldtextscnlfâ€” to describe the implicit dynamics allowing \oldtextscsde-based generative models to tap into latent abstractions and guide the generative process. Our theory, that required advancing the standard \oldtextscnlf formulation, culminates in a new system of joint \oldtextscsdes that fully describe the iterative process of data generation. Furthermore, we derived an information-theoretic measure to study the influence of latent abstractions, which provides a concrete understanding of the joint dynamics.

To root our theory into concrete examples, we collected experimental evidence by means of novel (and established) measurement strategies, that corroborates our understanding of diffusion models. Latent abstractions emerge according to an implicitly learned hierarchy, and can appear early on in the data generation process, much earlier than what is visible in the data domain. Our theory is especially useful as it allows analyses and measurements of generative pathways, opening up opportunities for a variety of applications, including image editing, and improved conditional generation.

7 Acknowledgments

G.F. and P.M were partially funded by project MUSECOM2 - AI-enabled MUltimodal SEmantic COMmunications and COMputing, in the Machine Learning-based Communication Systems, towards Wireless AI (WAI), Call 2022, ChistERA. M.M. acknowledges the financial support of the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Unionâ€™s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (AdG ELISA project, Grant agreement No. 101054746).

Appendix A Assumptions

Assumption 2.

Whenever we mention a filtration, we assume as usual that it is augmented with the Pâˆ’limit-fromP\mathrm{P}-roman_P - null sets, i.e. if the set Nğ‘Nitalic_N is such that Pâ¢(N)=0Pğ‘0\mathrm{P}(N)=0roman_P ( italic_N ) = 0, then all AâŠ†Nğ´ğ‘A\subseteq Nitalic_A âŠ† italic_N should be in the filtration.

Appendix B Proof of TheoremÂ 2

We start by combining EquationÂ 3 and EquationÂ 1

We begin by showing that it is a martingale. For any 0â‰¤Ï„â‰¤t0ğœğ‘¡0\leq\tau\leq t0 â‰¤ italic_Ï„ â‰¤ italic_t it holds

Appendix D Proof of TheoremÂ 4

where to obtain the last equality we used Lemma 5.4 in Xiong (2008). We also recall that, under QQ{\mathrm{Q}}roman_Q, the process (Ytâˆ’Y0)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0(Y_{t}-Y_{0})( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is independent of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X. Thus, since â„›t=Ïƒâ¢(â„›0âˆªÏƒâ¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tâˆ’Y0))subscriptâ„›ğ‘¡ğœsubscriptâ„›0ğœsubscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0\mathcal{R}_{t}=\sigma(\mathcal{R}_{0}\cup\sigma(Y_{0\leq s\leq t}-Y_{0}))caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) and dPdQ|â„±0Y,X=1evaluated-atPQsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘‹01\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}}{\differential{\mathrm{Q}}}\,|\,_{\mathcal{F}^{Y% ,X}_{0}}=1divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_Q end_ARG | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, we obtain ğ”¼Qâ¢[Ï•â¢(X)|â„›t]=ğ”¼Pâ¢[Ï•â¢(X)|â„›0]subscriptğ”¼Qdelimited-[]conditionalitalic-Ï•ğ‘‹subscriptâ„›ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalitalic-Ï•ğ‘‹subscriptâ„›0\mathbb{E}_{{\mathrm{Q}}}\left[\phi(X)\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}_{% \mathrm{P}}[\phi(X)\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{0}]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ï• ( italic_X ) | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ï• ( italic_X ) | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. Concluding and rearranging:

âŸ¨Ï€^tâ„›,Ï•âŸ©=âŸ¨Ï€^0â„›,Ï•âŸ©+âˆ«0tâŸ¨Ï€^sâ„›,Ï•â¢Hâ¢(Ys,â‹…,s)âŸ©â¢dYs.subscriptsuperscript^ğœ‹â„›ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptsuperscript^ğœ‹â„›0italic-Ï•superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscript^ğœ‹â„›ğ‘ italic-Ï•ğ»subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ â‹…ğ‘ subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ \langle\hat{\pi}^{\mathcal{R}}_{t},\phi\rangle=\langle\hat{\pi}^{\mathcal{R}}_% {0},\phi\rangle+\int_{0}^{t}\langle\hat{\pi}^{\mathcal{R}}_{s},\phi H(Y_{s},% \cdot,s)\rangle\differential Y_{s}.âŸ¨ over^ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• âŸ© = âŸ¨ over^ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• âŸ© + âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¨ over^ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹… , italic_s ) âŸ© start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Obviously by the same arguments âŸ¨Ï€^tâ„›,1âŸ©=ğ”¼Qâ¢[dPdQ|â„›t]=ğ”¼Qâ¢[Ïˆt|â„›t]subscriptsuperscript^ğœ‹â„›ğ‘¡1subscriptğ”¼Qdelimited-[]conditionalPQsubscriptâ„›ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Qdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğœ“ğ‘¡subscriptâ„›ğ‘¡\langle\hat{\pi}^{\mathcal{R}}_{t},1\rangle=\mathbb{E}_{{\mathrm{Q}}}[\frac{% \differential\mathrm{P}}{\differential{\mathrm{Q}}}\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{t}]=% \mathbb{E}_{{\mathrm{Q}}}\left[\psi_{t}\,|\,\mathcal{R}_{t}\right]âŸ¨ over^ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 âŸ© = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_Q end_ARG | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], and

âŸ¨Ï€^tâ„›,1âŸ©=1+âˆ«0tâŸ¨Ï€^sâ„›,Hâ¢(Ys,â‹…,s)âŸ©â¢dYs.subscriptsuperscript^ğœ‹â„›ğ‘¡11superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscript^ğœ‹â„›ğ‘ ğ»subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ â‹…ğ‘ subscriptğ‘Œğ‘ \langle\hat{\pi}^{\mathcal{R}}_{t},1\rangle=1+\int_{0}^{t}\langle\hat{\pi}^{% \mathcal{R}}_{s},H(Y_{s},\cdot,s)\rangle\differential Y_{s}.âŸ¨ over^ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 âŸ© = 1 + âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¨ over^ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_H ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹… , italic_s ) âŸ© start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (30)

From now on, for simplicity we assume that all the processes involved in our computations are 1111-dimensional. The extension to the multidimensional case is trivial. First, let us notice that, by (30) and ItÃ´â€™s lemma, it holds

Recalling (26) and rearranging the terms lead us to
