Appendix E Proof of TheoremÂ 5

The proof of this Theorem involves two separate parts. First, we should show the second equality in EquationÂ 7, i.e. âˆ«logâ¡dP#â¢Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t,Ï•dP#â¢Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tâ¢dP#â¢Ï•â¢dP#â¢Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t,Ï•=ğ”¼Pâ¢[logâ¡dP|â„›tdP|â„±tYâ¢dP|Ïƒâ¢(Ï•)]subscriptP#subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptP#subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptP#italic-Ï•subscriptP#subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]evaluated-atPsubscriptâ„›ğ‘¡evaluated-atevaluated-atPsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡Pğœitalic-Ï•\int\log\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t},\phi}}{% \differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t}}\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#\phi}}% \differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t},\phi}=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}% \left[\log\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{R}_{t}}}{\differential% \mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}}\differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\sigma(\phi% )}}\right]âˆ« roman_log divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï• ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ]. Then, we should prove that the r.h.s of EquationÂ 7 is equal to EquationÂ 8.

E.1 Part 1

We overload in this Section the notation adopted in the rest of the paper for sake of simplicity in exposition. A random variable Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X on a probability space (Î©,â„±,P)Î©â„±P(\Omega,\mathcal{F},\mathrm{P})( roman_Î© , caligraphic_F , roman_P ) is defined as a measurable mapping X:Î©â†’Î¨:ğ‘‹â†’Î©Î¨X:\Omega\rightarrow\Psiitalic_X : roman_Î© â†’ roman_Î¨, where the measure space (Î¨,ğ’¢)Î¨ğ’¢(\Psi,\mathcal{G})( roman_Î¨ , caligraphic_G ) satisfies the usual assumptions. To be precise, Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is measurable w.r.t. â„±â„±\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F if âˆ€Eâˆˆğ’¢,Xâˆ’1â¢(E)âˆˆâ„±formulae-sequencefor-allğ¸ğ’¢superscriptğ‘‹1ğ¸â„±\forall E\in\mathcal{G},X^{-1}(E)\in\mathcal{F}âˆ€ italic_E âˆˆ caligraphic_G , italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_E ) âˆˆ caligraphic_F, where Xâˆ’1â¢(E)={Ï‰âˆˆÎ©:Xâ¢(Ï‰)âˆˆE}superscriptğ‘‹1ğ¸conditional-setğœ”Î©ğ‘‹ğœ”ğ¸X^{-1}(E)=\{\omega\in\Omega:X(\omega)\in E\}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_E ) = { italic_Ï‰ âˆˆ roman_Î© : italic_X ( italic_Ï‰ ) âˆˆ italic_E }. Equivalently, âˆ€Eâˆˆğ’¢,âˆƒSâˆˆâ„±:Xâ¢(S)=E:formulae-sequencefor-allğ¸ğ’¢ğ‘†â„±ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ¸\forall E\in\mathcal{G},\exists S\in\mathcal{F}:X(S)=Eâˆ€ italic_E âˆˆ caligraphic_G , âˆƒ italic_S âˆˆ caligraphic_F : italic_X ( italic_S ) = italic_E. Of all the possible sigma-algebras which allow measurability, the sigma algebra induced by the random variable, Ïƒâ¢(X)ğœğ‘‹\sigma(X)italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X ), is the smallest one. It can be shown that Ïƒâ¢(X)=Xâˆ’1â¢(ğ’¢)={A=Xâˆ’1â¢(B)|Bâˆˆğ’¢}ğœğ‘‹superscriptğ‘‹1ğ’¢conditional-setğ´superscriptğ‘‹1ğµğµğ’¢\sigma(X)=X^{-1}(\mathcal{G})=\{A=X^{-1}(B)|B\in\mathcal{G}\}italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X ) = italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_G ) = { italic_A = italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_B ) | italic_B âˆˆ caligraphic_G }. We also denote by P#â¢X:ğ’¢â†’[0,1]:subscriptP#ğ‘‹â†’ğ’¢01\mathrm{P}_{\#}X\colon\mathcal{G}\to[0,1]roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X : caligraphic_G â†’ [ 0 , 1 ] the push-forward measure associated to Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X (i.e. the law), which is defined by the relation P#â¢Xâ¢(E)=Pâ¢(Xâˆ’1â¢(E))subscriptP#ğ‘‹ğ¸Psuperscriptğ‘‹1ğ¸\mathrm{P}_{\#X}(E)=\mathrm{P}(X^{-1}(E))roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_E ) = roman_P ( italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_E ) ) for any Eâˆˆğ’¢ğ¸ğ’¢E\in\mathcal{G}italic_E âˆˆ caligraphic_G. Moreover, for any ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}caligraphic_G-measurable Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, the following integration rule holds

Let us focus on (Î©,Ïƒâ¢(X),P)Î©ğœğ‘‹P(\Omega,\sigma(X),\mathrm{P})( roman_Î© , italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X ) , roman_P ) and let us consider a new measure QQ\mathrm{Q}roman_Q absolutely continuous w.r.t.Â PP\mathrm{P}roman_P. Radon-Nikodym theorem guarantees existence of a Ïƒâ¢(X)ğœğ‘‹\sigma(X)italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X )-measurable function Z:Î©â†’[0,+âˆ):ğ‘â†’Î©0Z\colon\Omega\to[0,+\infty)italic_Z : roman_Î© â†’ [ 0 , + âˆ ) (the â€œderivativeâ€ dQdP=ZQPğ‘\frac{\differential\mathrm{Q}}{\differential\mathrm{P}}=Zdivide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_Q end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P end_ARG = italic_Z) such that Qâ¢(A)=âˆ«AZâ¢dPQğ´subscriptğ´ğ‘P\mathrm{Q}(A)=\int_{A}Z\differential\mathrm{P}roman_Q ( italic_A ) = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P, for all AâˆˆÏƒâ¢(X)ğ´ğœğ‘‹A\in\sigma(X)italic_A âˆˆ italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X ). =âˆ«Î©ğŸEâ¢(Xâ¢(Ï‰))â¢fâ¢(Xâ¢(Ï‰))â¢dPâ¢(Ï‰)=âˆ«Î¨ğŸEâ¢(x)â¢fâ¢(x)â¢dP#â¢Xâ¢(x)=âˆ«Efâ¢(x)â¢dP#â¢Xâ¢(x).absentsubscriptÎ©subscript1ğ¸ğ‘‹ğœ”ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğœ”Pğœ”subscriptÎ¨subscript1ğ¸ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptP#ğ‘‹ğ‘¥subscriptğ¸ğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptP#ğ‘‹ğ‘¥\displaystyle=\int_{\Omega}\mathbf{1}_{E}(X(\omega))f(X(\omega))\differential% \mathrm{P}(\omega)=\int_{\Psi}\mathbf{1}_{E}(x)f(x)\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#% X}(x)=\int_{E}f(x)\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#X}(x).= âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ( italic_Ï‰ ) ) italic_f ( italic_X ( italic_Ï‰ ) ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P ( italic_Ï‰ ) = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¨ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_f ( italic_x ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) .

In summary, we have that dQ#â¢XdP#â¢X=fsubscriptQ#ğ‘‹subscriptP#ğ‘‹ğ‘“\frac{\differential\mathrm{Q}_{\#X}}{\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#X}}=fdivide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = italic_f, with f:Î¨â†’[0,+âˆ):ğ‘“â†’Î¨0f\colon\Psi\to[0,+\infty)italic_f : roman_Î¨ â†’ [ 0 , + âˆ ).

Finally, then,

âˆ«Î¨logâ¡(dP#â¢XdQ#â¢X)â¢dP#â¢X=âˆ’âˆ«Î¨logâ¡(f)â¢dP#â¢X=âˆ’âˆ«Î©logâ¡(fâ¢(X))â¢dP=âˆ«Î©logâ¡dPdQâ¢dP=ğ”¼Pâ¢[logâ¡dPdQ].subscriptÎ¨subscriptP#ğ‘‹subscriptQ#ğ‘‹subscriptP#ğ‘‹subscriptÎ¨ğ‘“subscriptP#ğ‘‹subscriptÎ©ğ‘“ğ‘‹PsubscriptÎ©PQPsubscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]PQ\displaystyle\int_{\Psi}\log(\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#X}}{% \differential\mathrm{Q}_{\#X}})\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#X}=-\int_{\Psi}\log(% f)\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#X}=-\int_{\Omega}\log(f(X))\differential\mathrm{P% }=\int_{\Omega}\log\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}}{\differential\mathrm{Q}}% \differential\mathrm{P}=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\log\frac{\differential\mathrm% {P}}{\differential\mathrm{Q}}].âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¨ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( start_ARG divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î¨ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log ( start_ARG italic_f ( italic_X ) end_ARG ) start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î© end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_Q end_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_Q end_ARG ] . (33)

What discussed so far, allows to prove that âˆ«logâ¡dP#â¢Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t,Ï•dP#â¢Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤tâ¢dP#â¢Ï•â¢dP#â¢Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t,Ï•=ğ”¼Pâ¢[logâ¡dP|â„›tdP|â„±tYâ¢dP|Ïƒâ¢(Ï•)]subscriptP#subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptP#subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptP#italic-Ï•subscriptP#subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]evaluated-atPsubscriptâ„›ğ‘¡evaluated-atevaluated-atPsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡Pğœitalic-Ï•\int\log\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t},\phi}}{% \differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t}}\differential\mathrm{P}_{\#\phi}}% \differential\mathrm{P}_{\#Y_{0\leq s\leq t},\phi}=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}% \left[\log\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{R}_{t}}}{\differential% \mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}}\differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\sigma(\phi% )}}\right]âˆ« roman_log divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT # italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï• ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ]. Indeed:

  • â€¢

    Consider on the space (Î©,â„›t,P|â„›t)Î©subscriptâ„›ğ‘¡evaluated-atPsubscriptâ„›ğ‘¡(\Omega,\mathcal{R}_{t},\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{R}_{t}})( roman_Î© , caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) the random variable T=(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t,Ï•)ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•T=(Y_{0\leq s\leq t},\phi)italic_T = ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• ).   • â€¢

    Then the desired equality follows from EquationÂ 33.

E.2 Part 2

Before proceeding, remember that the following holds: for all â„›tâ€²âŠ†â„›tsubscriptsuperscriptâ„›â€²ğ‘¡subscriptâ„›ğ‘¡\mathcal{R}^{\prime}_{t}\subseteq\mathcal{R}_{t}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Qâ„›|â„›tâ€²=Qâ„›â€²|â„›tâ€²evaluated-atsuperscriptQâ„›subscriptsuperscriptâ„›â€²ğ‘¡evaluated-atsuperscriptQsuperscriptâ„›â€²subscriptsuperscriptâ„›â€²ğ‘¡{\mathrm{Q}^{\mathcal{R}}}\,|\,_{\mathcal{R}^{\prime}_{t}}=\mathrm{Q}^{% \mathcal{R}^{\prime}}\,|\,_{\mathcal{R}^{\prime}_{t}}roman_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We restart from the r.h.s. of EquationÂ 7. Thanks to the chain rule for Radon-Nykodim derivatives

Consequently

ğ”¼Pâ¢[logâ¡dP|â„›tdP|â„±tYâ¢dP|Ïƒâ¢(Ï•)]=ğ”¼Pâ¢[logâ¡Ïˆtâ„›âˆ’logâ¡Ïˆtâ„±Y]+â„â¢(Y0;Ï•)subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]evaluated-atPsubscriptâ„›ğ‘¡evaluated-atevaluated-atPsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡Pğœitalic-Ï•subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğœ“â„›ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğœ“superscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡â„subscriptğ‘Œ0italic-Ï•\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}\left[\log\frac{\differential\mathrm{P}\,|% \,_{\mathcal{R}_{t}}}{\differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}}% \differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\sigma(\phi)}}\right]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}% \left[\log\psi^{\mathcal{R}}_{t}-\log\psi^{\mathcal{F}^{Y}}_{t}\right]+% \mathcal{I}(Y_{0};\phi)blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï• ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_log italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] + caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• )

Actually, the result in the main is in a slightly different form. To show equivalence, it is necessary to prove that

Appendix F Proof of TheoremÂ 6

F.1 Proof of EquationÂ 9

The inequality is proven considering that: i)

â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t;Ï•)=ğ”¼P|â„±tYÃ—P|Ïƒâ¢(Ï•)â¢[Î·â¢(dP|â„›tdP|â„±tYâ¢dP|Ïƒâ¢(Ï•))]â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptğ”¼evaluated-atevaluated-atPsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡Pğœitalic-Ï•delimited-[]ğœ‚evaluated-atPsubscriptâ„›ğ‘¡evaluated-atevaluated-atPsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡Pğœitalic-Ï•\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{F}^{% Y}_{t}}\times\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\sigma(\phi)}}\left[\eta\left(\frac{% \differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{R}_{t}}}{\differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{% \mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}}\differential\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\sigma(\phi)}}\right)\right]caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï• ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_Î· ( divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_P | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï• ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ]

and

start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• ) ] and iii) that Jensenâ€™s inequality holds (Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· is convex on its domain)

â‰¤ğ”¼P|â„±tYÃ—P|Ïƒâ¢(Ï•)â¢[ğ”¼P|â„±tYÃ—P|Ïƒâ¢(Ï•)â¢[Î·â¢(dP|â„›tdP|â„±tYâ¢dP|Ïƒâ¢(Ï•))|Ïƒâ¢(Y~t,Ï•)]]absentsubscriptğ”¼evaluated-atevaluated-atPsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡Pğœitalic-Ï•delimited-[]subscriptğ”¼evaluated-atevaluated-atPsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡Pğœitalic-Ï•delimited-[]conditionalğœ‚evaluated-atPsubscriptâ„›ğ‘¡evaluated-atevaluated-atPsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡Pğœitalic-Ï•ğœsubscript~ğ‘Œğ‘¡italic-Ï•\displaystyle\qquad\quad\leq\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}\,|\,_{\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}}% F.2 Proof of Conditional Independence and Mutual Information Equality

Formally the condition of conditional independence given Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ is satisfied if for any a1,a2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2a_{1},a_{2}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT positive random variables which are respectively Ïƒâ¢(X)ğœğ‘‹\sigma(X)italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X ) and â„±tYsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measurable, the following holds: ğ”¼Pâ¢[a1â¢a2|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]=ğ”¼Pâ¢[a1|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]â¢ğ”¼Pâ¢[a2|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ‘1ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ‘2ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[a_{1}a_{2}\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t})]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}% }[a_{1}\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t})]\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[a_{2}\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] (see for instance VanÂ Putten & van Schuppen (1985)).

The sigma-algebra Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\sigma(\pi_{t})italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is by definition the smallest one that makes Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measurable. Since Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is â„±tYsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT measurable, clearly Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)âŠ†â„±tYğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\sigma(\pi_{t})\subseteq\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âŠ† caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By the very definition of conditional expectation, ğ”¼Pâ¢[a1|â„±tY]=âŸ¨Ï€t,a1âŸ©subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ‘1subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡subscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘1\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[a_{1}\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]=\langle\pi_{t},a_{1}\rangleblackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ©, which is an Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\sigma(\pi_{t})italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) measurable quantity. Then ğ”¼P[a1a2|Ïƒ(Ï€t)]=ğ”¼P[ğ”¼P[a1a2|â„±tY]|Ïƒ(Ï€t)]=ğ”¼P[ğ”¼P[a1|â„±tY]a2|Ïƒ(Ï€t)]=ğ”¼P[ğ”¼P[âŸ¨Ï€t,a1âŸ©a2|Ïƒ(Ï€t)]=âŸ¨Ï€t,a1âŸ©ğ”¼P[a2|Ïƒ(Ï€t)]\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[a_{1}a_{2}\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t})]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}% }[\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[a_{1}a_{2}\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{% t})]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[a_{1}\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}% \rangle\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[a_{2}\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Since âŸ¨Ï€t,a1âŸ©=ğ”¼Pâ¢[âŸ¨Ï€t,a1âŸ©|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]=ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğ”¼Pâ¢[a1|â„±tY]|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]=ğ”¼Pâ¢[a1|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]subscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘1ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ‘1subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ‘1ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\langle\pi_{t},a_{1}\rangle=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\langle\pi_{t},a_{1}% \rangle\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t})]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[a% _{1}\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t})]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[a_{% 1}\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t})]âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âŸ¨ italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ], the proof of conditional independence is concluded.

In summary, Ïƒâ¢(X)ğœğ‘‹\sigma(X)italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X ) and â„±tYsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are conditionally independent given Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\sigma(\pi_{t})italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (âŠ‚â„±tYabsentsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\subset\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}âŠ‚ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). This implies that Pâ¢(A|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t))=Pâ¢(A|â„±tY),âˆ€AâˆˆÏƒâ¢(X)formulae-sequencePconditionalğ´ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡Pconditionalğ´subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡for-allğ´ğœğ‘‹\mathrm{P}(A\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t}))=\mathrm{P}(A\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}),\quad% \forall A\in\sigma(X)roman_P ( italic_A | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = roman_P ( italic_A | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , âˆ€ italic_A âˆˆ italic_Ïƒ ( italic_X ), or equivalently ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğŸâ¢(A)|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]=ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğŸâ¢(A)|â„±tY]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditional1ğ´ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditional1ğ´subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbf{1}(A)\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t})]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm% {P}}[\mathbf{1}(A)\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. To prove this, it is sufficient to show that for any Bâˆˆâ„±tYğµsubscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡B\in\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t}italic_B âˆˆ caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğŸâ¢(A)|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]â¢ğŸâ¢(B)]=ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğŸâ¢(A)â¢ğŸâ¢(B)]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditional1ğ´ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡1ğµsubscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]1ğ´1ğµ\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbf{1}(A)\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{% t})]\mathbf{1}(B)]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbf{1}(A)\mathbf{1}(B)]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] bold_1 ( italic_B ) ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) bold_1 ( italic_B ) ]. By standard properties of conditional expectation ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğŸâ¢(A)|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]â¢ğŸâ¢(B)]=ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğŸâ¢(A)|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]â¢ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğŸâ¢(B)|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditional1ğ´ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡1ğµsubscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditional1ğ´ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditional1ğµğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbf{1}(A)\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{% t})]\mathbf{1}(B)]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbf{1}(% A)\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t})]\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbf{1}(B)\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t% })]]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] bold_1 ( italic_B ) ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_B ) | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ]. Then, ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğŸâ¢(A)|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]â¢ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğŸâ¢(B)|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]]=ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğŸâ¢(A)â¢ğŸâ¢(B)|Ïƒâ¢(Ï€t)]]=ğ”¼Pâ¢[ğŸâ¢(A)â¢ğŸâ¢(B)]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditional1ğ´ğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditional1ğµğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditional1ğ´1ğµğœsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]1ğ´1ğµ\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbf{1}(A)\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{% t})]\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbf{1}(B)\,|\,\sigma(\pi_{t})]]=\mathbb{E}_{% \mathrm{P}}[\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbf{1}(A)\mathbf{1}(B)\,|\,\sigma(\pi_% {t})]]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[\mathbf{1}(A)\mathbf{1}(B)]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_B ) | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) bold_1 ( italic_B ) | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] ] = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_1 ( italic_A ) bold_1 ( italic_B ) ].

The mutual information equality is then proved considering that Appendix G A technical note

As anticipated in the main, 1 might be incompatible with the other technical assumptions in AppendixÂ A. The problem might arise for singularities in the drift term at time t=Tğ‘¡ğ‘‡t=Titalic_t = italic_T, which are usually present in the construction of dynamics satisfying 1 like stochastic bridges. This mathematical subtlety can be more clearly interpreted by noticing that when 1 is satisfied the evolution of the posterior process Ï€tsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¡\pi_{t}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at time Tğ‘‡Titalic_T can occupy a portion of the space of dimensionality lower than at any Tâˆ’Ïµğ‘‡italic-ÏµT-\epsilonitalic_T - italic_Ïµ, Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0. Or, we can notice that if 1 is satisfied, â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤T;V)=â„â¢(V;V)â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘‡ğ‘‰â„ğ‘‰ğ‘‰\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq T};V)=\mathcal{I}(V;V)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_V ) = caligraphic_I ( italic_V ; italic_V ) which can be equal to infinity depending on the actual structure of ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S and the mapping Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V. In many cases, a simple technical solution is to consider in the analysis only dynamics of the process in the time interval [0,T)0ğ‘‡[0,T)[ 0 , italic_T )333This is akin to the discussion of arbitrage strategies in finance when the initial filtration is augmented with knowledge of the future value at certain time instants, and the fact that while the new process adapted w.r.t the new filtration is also a martingale w.r.t. a given new measure for all tâˆˆ[0,T)ğ‘¡0ğ‘‡t\in[0,T)italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , italic_T ), it fails to do so for t=Tğ‘¡ğ‘‡t=Titalic_t = italic_T (thus giving an arbitrage opportunity)..In the reduced time interval [0,T)0ğ‘‡[0,T)[ 0 , italic_T ), the technical assumptions are generally shown to be satisfied. For the practical purposes explored in this work this restriction makes no difference, and consequently neglect it for the rest of our discussion.

Appendix H Linear Diffusion Models

Consider the particular case of linear generative diffusion models Song etÂ al. (2021), which are widely adopted in the literature and by practitioners. We consider the particular case of EquationÂ 11, where the function Fğ¹Fitalic_F has linear expression

Y^t=Y^0âˆ’Î±â¢âˆ«0tY^sâ¢ds+W^t,subscript^ğ‘Œğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘Œ0ğ›¼superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘Œğ‘ ğ‘ subscript^ğ‘Šğ‘¡\hat{Y}_{t}=\hat{Y}_{0}-\alpha\int\limits_{0}^{t}\hat{Y}_{s}\differential s+% \hat{W}_{t},over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î± âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s + over^ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (34)

for a given Î±â‰¥0ğ›¼0\alpha\geq 0italic_Î± â‰¥ 0. The next result is a particular case of TheoremÂ 7.

As discussed in the main paper, we can now show that the same generative dynamics can be obtained under the \oldtextscnlf framework we present in this work, without the need to explicitly defining a backward and a forward process. In particular, we can directly select a observation function that corresponds to an Orstein-Uhlenbeck bridge (Mazzolo, 2017; Corlay, 2013), consequently satisfying 1, and obtain the generative dynamics of classical diffusion models. In particular we consider the following about Hğ»Hitalic_H444Notice that with Hğ»Hitalic_H selected as in 7 the validity of the theory considered is restricted to the time interval [0,T)0ğ‘‡[0,T)[ 0 , italic_T ), see also AppendixÂ G.:

Assumption 7.

In summary, the particular case of EquationÂ 1 (which is â„±Y,Xsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘‹\mathcal{F}^{Y,X}caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_X end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT adapted) under 7, can be transformed into a generative model leveraging TheoremÂ 2, since 1 holds. which is nothing but EquationÂ 35 after some simple algebraic manipulation. The only relevant detail worth deeper exposition is the clarification about the actual computation of expectation of interest. If PP\mathrm{P}roman_P is selected such that Y^tsubscript^ğ‘Œğ‘¡\hat{Y}_{t}over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT solves EquationÂ 34, we have that

ğ”¼Pâ¢(V|â„±tY)=ğ”¼Pâ¢(YT|Ïƒâ¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t))=ğ”¼Pâ¢(Y^0|Ïƒâ¢(Y^Tâˆ’tâ‰¤sâ‰¤T))=ğ”¼Pâ¢(Y^0|Ïƒâ¢(Y^Tâˆ’t))=ğ”¼Pâ¢(V|Ïƒâ¢(Yt)),subscriptğ”¼Pconditionalğ‘‰subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Œğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pconditionalsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡ğœsubscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pconditionalsubscript^ğ‘Œ0ğœsubscript^ğ‘Œğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğ‘‡subscriptğ”¼Pconditionalsubscript^ğ‘Œ0ğœsubscript^ğ‘Œğ‘‡ğ‘¡subscriptğ”¼Pconditionalğ‘‰ğœsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}(V\,|\,\mathcal{F}^{Y}_{t})=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}(Y_{% T}\,|\,\sigma(Y_{0\leq s\leq t}))=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}(\hat{Y}_{0}\,|\,% \sigma(\hat{Y}_{T-t\leq s\leq T}))=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}(\hat{Y}_{0}\,|\,% \sigma(\hat{Y}_{T-t}))=\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}(V\,|\,\sigma(Y_{t})),blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_V | caligraphic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_Ïƒ ( over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_V | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , (38)

where the second to last equality is due to the Markov nature of Y^tsubscript^ğ‘Œğ‘¡\hat{Y}_{t}over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Moreover, in this particular case we can express the mutual information â„â¢(Y0â‰¤sâ‰¤t;Ï•)=â„â¢(Yt;Ï•)â„subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-Ï•â„subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡italic-Ï•\mathcal{I}(Y_{0\leq s\leq t};\phi)=\mathcal{I}(Y_{t};\phi)caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ) = caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ) ( where we removed the past of Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y since the following Markov chain holds Ï•â†’Y^0â†’Y^t>0â†’italic-Ï•subscript^ğ‘Œ0â†’subscript^ğ‘Œğ‘¡0\phi\rightarrow\hat{Y}_{0}\rightarrow\hat{Y}_{t>0}italic_Ï• â†’ over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ over^ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) can be expressed in the simpler form

â„â¢(Yt;Ï•)=â„â¢(Y0;Ï•)+12â¢ğ”¼Pâ¢[âˆ«0tms2â¢â€–ğ”¼Pâ¢[V|Ïƒâ¢(Ys)]âˆ’ğ”¼Pâ¢[V|Ïƒâ¢(Ys,Ï•)]â€–2â¢ds]â„subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡italic-Ï•â„subscriptğ‘Œ0italic-Ï•12subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘š2ğ‘ superscriptnormsubscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalğ‘‰ğœsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘ subscriptğ”¼Pdelimited-[]conditionalğ‘‰ğœsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘ italic-Ï•2ğ‘ \mathcal{I}(Y_{t};\phi)=\mathcal{I}(Y_{0};\phi)+\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm% {P}}\left[\int_{0}^{t}m^{2}_{s}\norm{\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[V\,|\,\sigma(Y_{s% })]-\mathbb{E}_{\mathrm{P}}[V\,|\,\sigma(Y_{s},\phi)]}^{2}\differential s\right]caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ) = caligraphic_I ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï• ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_V | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_V | italic_Ïƒ ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Ï• ) ] end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_s ] (39)

matching the result described in Franzese etÂ al. (2023), obtained with the formalism of time reversal of \oldtextscsdes.

Appendix I Discussion about 7

This is easily checked thanks to the following equality

Yt=Y0â¢m0mt+Vâ¢m0mTâˆ’t+âˆ«0tmsmtâ¢dWs.subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0subscriptğ‘š0subscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘š0subscriptğ‘šğ‘‡ğ‘¡superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘šğ‘ subscriptğ‘šğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Šğ‘ Y_{t}=Y_{0}\frac{m_{0}}{m_{t}}+V\frac{m_{0}}{m_{T-t}}+\int_{0}^{t}\frac{m_{s}}% {m_{t}}\differential W_{s}.italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + italic_V divide start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (40)

To avoid cluttering the notation, we define ft=dlogâ¡mtdtsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘¡f_{t}=\frac{\differential\log m_{t}}{\differential t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP roman_log italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_t end_ARG. To show that EquationÂ 40 is true, it is sufficient to observe i) that initial conditions are met and ii) that the time differential of the process is the correct one. We proceed to show that indeed the second condition holds (the first one is trivially observed to be true).

dYt=âˆ’Î±â¢Y0â¢coshâ¡(Î±â¢(Tâˆ’t))sinhâ¡(Î±â¢T)+Î±â¢râ¢(X)â¢coshâ¡(Î±â¢t)sinhâ¡(Î±â¢T)âˆ’Î±â¢coshâ¡(Î±â¢(Tâˆ’t))â¢âˆ«0t1sinhâ¡(Î±â¢(Tâˆ’s))â¢dWs+dWtsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ›¼subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ›¼ğ‘Ÿğ‘‹ğ›¼ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ›¼ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ‘¡superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡1ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ‘ subscriptğ‘Šğ‘ subscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡\displaystyle\differential Y_{t}=-\alpha Y_{0}\frac{\cosh(\alpha(T-t))}{\sinh(% \alpha T)}+\alpha r(X)\frac{\cosh(\alpha t)}{\sinh(\alpha T)}-\alpha\cosh(% \alpha(T-t))\int_{0}^{t}\frac{1}{\sinh(\alpha(T-s))}\differential W_{s}+% \differential W_{t}start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_Î± italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_cosh ( start_ARG italic_Î± ( italic_T - italic_t ) end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_sinh ( italic_Î± italic_T ) end_ARG + italic_Î± italic_r ( italic_X ) divide start_ARG roman_cosh ( start_ARG italic_Î± italic_t end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_sinh ( italic_Î± italic_T ) end_ARG - italic_Î± roman_cosh ( start_ARG italic_Î± ( italic_T - italic_t ) end_ARG ) âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_sinh ( italic_Î± ( italic_T - italic_s ) ) end_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=âˆ’Î±â¢coshâ¡(Î±â¢(Tâˆ’t))sinhâ¡(Î±â¢(Tâˆ’t))â¢(Y0â¢sinhâ¡(Î±â¢(Tâˆ’t))sinhâ¡(Î±â¢T)+âˆ«0tsinhâ¡(Î±â¢(Tâˆ’t))sinhâ¡(Î±â¢(Tâˆ’s))â¢dWs)+Î±â¢râ¢(X)â¢coshâ¡(Î±â¢t)sinhâ¡(Î±â¢T)+dWtabsentğ›¼ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘Œ0ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘‡superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ‘ subscriptğ‘Šğ‘ ğ›¼ğ‘Ÿğ‘‹ğ›¼ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡\displaystyle=-\alpha\frac{\cosh(\alpha(T-t))}{\sinh(\alpha(T-t))}\left(Y_{0}% \frac{\sinh(\alpha(T-t))}{\sinh(\alpha T)}+\int_{0}^{t}\frac{\sinh(\alpha(T-t)% )}{\sinh(\alpha(T-s))}\differential W_{s}\right)+\alpha r(X)\frac{\cosh(\alpha t% )}{\sinh(\alpha T)}+\differential W_{t}= - italic_Î± divide start_ARG roman_cosh ( start_ARG italic_Î± ( italic_T - italic_t ) end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_sinh ( italic_Î± ( italic_T - italic_t ) ) end_ARG ( italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_sinh ( italic_Î± ( italic_T - italic_t ) ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_sinh ( italic_Î± italic_T ) end_ARG + âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_sinh ( italic_Î± ( italic_T - italic_t ) ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_sinh ( italic_Î± ( italic_T - italic_s ) ) end_ARG start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_Î± italic_r ( italic_X ) divide start_ARG roman_cosh ( start_ARG italic_Î± italic_t end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_sinh ( italic_Î± italic_T ) end_ARG + start_DIFFOP roman_d end_DIFFOP italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

where the result is obtained considering that

=eÎ±â¢T+eâˆ’Î±â¢(Tâˆ’2â¢t)âˆ’eÎ±â¢(Tâˆ’2â¢t)âˆ’eâˆ’Î±â¢TeÎ±â¢(Tâˆ’t)âˆ’eâˆ’Î±â¢(Tâˆ’t)+(eÎ±â¢t+eâˆ’Î±â¢t)eÎ±â¢Tâˆ’eâˆ’Î±â¢Tabsentsuperscriptğ‘’ğ›¼ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘’ğ›¼ğ‘‡2ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ›¼ğ‘‡2ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ›¼ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘’ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ›¼ğ‘‡ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ›¼ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ›¼ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’ğ›¼ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘’ğ›¼ğ‘‡\displaystyle\qquad=\frac{\frac{e^{\alpha T}+e^{-\alpha(T-2t)}-e^{\alpha(T-2t)% }-e^{-\alpha T}}{e^{\alpha(T-t)}-e^{-\alpha(T-t)}}+\left(e^{\alpha t}+e^{-% \alpha t}\right)}{e^{\alpha T}-e^{-\alpha T}}= divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î± italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î± ( italic_T - 2 italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î± ( italic_T - 2 italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î± italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î± ( italic_T - italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î± ( italic_T - italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + ( italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î± italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î± italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î± italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î± italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG

Appendix J Experimental Details

J.1 Dataset details

The Shapes3D datasetÂ (Kim & Mnih, 2018) includes the following attributes and the number of classes for each, as shown in TableÂ 1.

J.2 Unconditional Diffusion Model Training

We train the unconditional denoising score network using the NCSN++ architecture (Song etÂ al., 2021), which corresponds to a \oldtextscU-NetÂ (Ronneberger etÂ al., 2015). The model is trained from scratch using the score-matching objective. The training hyperparameters are summarized in TableÂ 2.

J.3 Linear Probing Experiment Details

In the linear probing experiments, we train a linear classifier on the feature maps extracted from the denoising score network at various noise levels Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. The training details are provided in TableÂ 3.

J.4 Mutual Information Estimation Experiment Details

For mutual information estimation, we train a conditional diffusion model using the same NCSN++ architecture as before. The conditioning is incorporated by adding a distinct class embedding for each label present in the input image, added to the input embedding along with the timestep embedding. The hyperparameters are the same as those used for the unconditional diffusion model (see TableÂ 2).

To calculate the mutual information, we use EquationÂ 39, estimating the integral using the midpoint rule with 999 points uniformly spaced in [0,T]0ğ‘‡[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ].

J.5 Forking Experiment Details

In the forking experiments, we use a ResNet50 (He etÂ al., 2016) model with an additional linear layer, trained from scratch, to classify the generated images and assess label coherence across forks. The training details for the classifier are summarized in TableÂ 4.

During the sampling process of the forking experiment, we use the settings summarized in TableÂ 5.

J.6 Linear probing on raw data

In FigureÂ 5, we evaluate the performance of linear probes trained on features maps extracted from the denoiser network, and show compare their log probability accuracy with a linear probe trained on the raw, noisy input and a random guesser. Throughout the generative process, linear probes obtain higher accuracy than the baselines: for large noise levels, a linear probe on raw input data fails, whereas the inner layers of the denoising network extract features that are sufficient to discern latent labels.
